TITLE: Are you worried about landing that first job out of college? Here's a look at the 'most employable' degrees
SUMMARY: A recent study found that a bachelor's degree in mathematics gives students the highest chances to secure a job right after graduation, followed by chemistry.

TITLE: Here's how ABLE accounts, special needs trusts differ ... and how they can work together
SUMMARY: Those with special needs must shelter assets carefully to not be disqualified from government aid. That's where special needs trusts and ABLE accounts come in.

TITLE: ‘Once-in-a-generation’ prescription drug pricing reform could be coming. Here’s what we know
SUMMARY: A Democratic bill calls for letting Medicare negotiate the price of prescription drugs. The change may result in significant savings for families, experts say.

TITLE: House Democrats push for Biden’s billionaire minimum income tax
SUMMARY: House Democrats have introduced the Billionaire Minimum Income Tax Act, calling for a 20% levy on total income for households worth more than $100 million.

TITLE: Here are 4 key things to consider if you actually hit the $1.28 billion Mega Millions jackpot
SUMMARY: While the odds are stacked against you snaring the top prize, it's worth giving thought to what you actually would do if you were to win.

TITLE: Is this a recession or not? While it's 'not entirely clear,' here's what it could mean for American consumers
SUMMARY: While the current economic doldrums may look different from previous downturns, there are certain things that remain the same.

TITLE: The Mega Millions jackpot has now surged to $1.28 billion. This is the tax bill if you happen to win
SUMMARY: Strong ticket sales have pushed the jackpot up to $1.28 billion for Friday night's drawing. It's now the third-largest lottery prize ever.

TITLE: U.S. economy continues to shrink and many aren't prepared for an economic downturn. Here's what advisors are telling clients as recession fears grow
SUMMARY: As the U.S. economy shrinks for a second straight quarter, many aren't prepared for an economic downturn. Here's what advisors are telling their clients.

TITLE: The cost to borrow is very expensive. Here are the best money moves to make after the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes
SUMMARY: Everything from student loans, car loans, mortgages and credit cards will be impacted by the Fed's back-to-back 0.75-percentage-point interest rate hikes.

TITLE: Considering a job change? Experts explain how to ace that 'Great Reshuffle' career move
SUMMARY: If you are considering a job switch before the labor market cools, here’s what employers want to see on your resume — and the most common mistakes to avoid.

TITLE: The Federal Reserve's latest interest rate hike will mean a better return on your savings. Here's what to expect
SUMMARY: Savers are poised to get a better return on their money after the latest bump to interest rates. But it will be a while before that competes with inflation.

TITLE: 'The disruption for a person's financial security is enormous.' Gaps in access to paid leave may lead to financial hardships, report finds.
SUMMARY: While Covid-19 prompted efforts to increase access to paid leave on federal, state and employer fronts, significant gaps in access to these benefits persist.

TITLE: Here's how advisors are shifting clients' portfolios as the Federal Reserve again hikes rates by 75 basis points
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve on Wednesday raised its interest rates again, by another 75 basis points, to combat soaring inflation. Here's how portfolios are shifting.

TITLE: Here's what the Federal Reserve's back-to-back 75-basis point interest rate hikes mean for you
SUMMARY: The Fed raised interest rates by another three-quarters of a point. Here's how that affects borrowers and savers now and down the road.

TITLE: Are you deep in credit card debt? Here's when it may make sense to tap your retirement savings
SUMMARY: As credit card balances rise, more Americans may be considering tapping their nest egg to reduce the debt. Here's what experts say you should first consider.

TITLE: Telehealth expansion for Medicare enrollees would be extended under a bill poised for House vote
SUMMARY: The measure aims to prevent temporary changes from expiring soon after the pandemic-related public health emergency ends.

TITLE: With 13 years until Social Security’s funds are projected to run out, Washington Democrats have some proposals to strengthen the program
SUMMARY: With 13 years until Social Security’s funds are projected to run out, Democrats want to extend that timeline while also making benefits more generous.

TITLE: The Mega Millions jackpot is now up to $830 million. Here's how much would go to taxes if there's a winner
SUMMARY: Ahead of Tuesday night's draw, the jackpot has already been adjusted upward twice and now is an estimated $830 million.

TITLE: Millennials' average net worth more than doubled during the pandemic. Here’s what advisors say they should do next
SUMMARY: Millennials' average net worth more than doubled during the pandemic, and real estate makes up more than one-third of their financial assets.

TITLE: Student loan servicers told to hold off on sending out billing notices, a sign payment pause may be extended
SUMMARY: Student loan servicers have been instructed to hold off on the process of restarting borrowers' payments. The bills are scheduled to resume after Aug. 31.

TITLE: Gen Z is stashing away 14% of income for retirement — more than older generations, study shows
SUMMARY: The youngest adults in the workforce are beating out their older counterparts when it comes to saving for their post-working years.

TITLE: Nearly half of all Americans are falling deeper in debt as inflation continues to boost costs
SUMMARY: With inflation hitting a 40-year high, Americans are struggling to keep up with rising prices and putting less money aside for emergencies, several studies show.

TITLE: More Americans plan to tap Social Security retirement benefits early and continue working amid economic uncertainty, survey finds
SUMMARY: The Covid-19 pandemic has prompted high inflation and economic uncertainty. Now, more people are planning to turn to Social Security retirement benefits early.

TITLE: The Biden administration is considering forgiving the student debt for millions of Americans. Here's why
SUMMARY: The Biden administration is considering forgiving the student debt for millions of Americans. Here are some of the reasons why.

TITLE: More employers turn to company-wide vacation breaks to encourage worker well-being
SUMMARY: A few companies offer a new perk to give employees a real break from their work: company-wide holidays when everyone is off at the same time.

TITLE: With inflation causing a spike in college costs, here are some tax breaks worth exploring to help cash-strapped families
SUMMARY: Some colleges are raising tuition by as much as 5% amid soaring inflation and other pressures. But these tax breaks may offer relief for cash-strapped families.

TITLE: Nearly 20% of Americans are afraid to check their credit card statements as interest rates approach an all-time high
SUMMARY: As credit card debt swells and interest rates spike, many spenders are fearful about high balances. Here's what to know if you're dealing with credit card debt.

TITLE: Travelers should act now to capitalize on a strong dollar for trips abroad, says travel editor: 'Don't be too greedy'
SUMMARY: Americans planning a trip abroad can best take advantage of favorable exchange rates by booking hotels, rental cars and other services now instead of waiting.

TITLE: 'High volatility' includes 'sharp' up days, too. Here's why it's smart to stay invested in the market
SUMMARY: With the stock market flashing red day after day, investors may be eyeing the exit sign. They'd be better off staying put.

TITLE: More advisors turn to alternative investments to further diversify their clients in volatile market
SUMMARY: After battling downturns in the stock and bond markets, more advisors are turning to alternative investments, according to a recent survey.
